Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:Before getting a divorce, what did the wife feel who was doing all the work? Choices:  A: harder B: anguish C: bitterness D: tears E: sadness<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: "Do you care about what other people think?"<n>"No"<n>"What makes you think she wasn't an intelligent woman?"<n>"She did this and she did that!"<n>"Did she do this and this and this too?"<n>"No" but there was that one thing...<n>"Were you doing any of the work when you got married?"<n><n>### Input 2:<n>"You still believe we are equal?"<n>"Yes I do"<n>"Did we always have equal rights?"<n>No.<n><n>### Question(s): When did women get the right to vote?<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a Response that appropriately completes each request.<n><n>## Sample Solution 1:<n>- - -<n>Answering questions with only one choice is simple.<n><n>Q: What do I need to do to get my paycheck?<n><n>A: Just answer all your questions<n>Q: Do you feel you justified your actions today?<n><n>A: Oh, well, you see....<n>In short, the instruction has only one way to answer it.<n>You may also need to include a question mark or the correct punctuation.<n><n>Q: Are you ready to go?<n><n>If you are able to tell me the correct answer to a question or solve a task, you need to follow the direction of the instruction before writing responses. If you're not able, you might need to ask questions in the first part.<n><n>Q: Why don't we look at the problem from a different angle?<n><n>Q: Do you think I can succeed in everything I do?<n><n>A: It's not possible without support from the people you interact with.<n><n>However, if the answer is not too short, you should put the question in your statement, not in your answer.<n><n>Q: When did women get the legal right to vote?<n>  <n>      A: That was a big shock.<n>      A: Before they were allowed to.<n>      A: Women's suffrage was denied.<n>      A: In 1920 women's suffrage was granted.<n>      A: There were no laws prohibiting women voting.<n>      A: Some women were not eligible to vote<n>        A: Women were given the right to vote.<n>      A: They didn't vote.<n><n>## Sample solution

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:Too many people want exotic snakes.  The demand is driving what to carry them? Choices:  A: ditch B: shop C: north america D: pet shops E: outdoors<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>The teacher wanted to see the student include examples in their work because having examples of how the ideas were proven and presented will help the student feel better about themselves and their work. A: prepare dinner: The people who want to cook snakes as a meal probably would not be able to find exotic snakes anywhere else and therefore would be able to eat them. B: evaluate progress: Having the students evaluate their own progress will help them to be more confident in their work. C: include examples: The students in her classroom all need to know how to include examples in their work. That is a skill they will need to know throughout their school years. D: work in school: The students who want to have exotic snakes are all not going to be able to work with them in their area of school. But students in areas such as Biology, zoology, and/or herpetology will get to have the chance to work with exotic snakes. E: prove their point: They want to prove that there is demand for exotic snakes. They will be able to do that by showing an example of how the demand has increased over the years. <n>```<n><n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: living room B: dog park C: basket D: small apartment E: big house<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>```<n>#!/usr/bin/env python<n><n>'''<n>This program uses data of a specific form for data processing. The following paragraphs explain the format of data that is input, how to use it, and how the processed data is output.<n><n>The first line of the input data will contain the name of students. Each student will have one line of input.<n><n>The first part of the line will be their names. Each name will be one word.<n><n>The second part of the line will contain the answers in a list of strings. Each one of these strings represent the answer that the student wrote.<n><n>Each string will be a number enclosed in quotes in no order.<n><n>An example could be the line "Susha,2,4" which represents a student who is Susha and who wrote the answers 2 and 4.<n><n>The next line of output is a line consisting of the names of the students in a list without commas.<n><n>The last line of the output is the list that has the answers in the correct order with a corresponding number. <n><n>An example would be the following line "Bob,4,7,6,5" which would represent the output of the previous line if the answers of the student called Bob were the ones given in the question and the answers he gave were 4,7,6 and 5.<n>'''<n><n>def main():<n>    students = []<n>    answers = []<n>    studentsNames = []<n>    answersToCheck = []<n>    namesForOutput = []<n>    with open('student_names_file.txt', 'r') as f:<n>        lines = f.readlines()<n>        for line in lines:<n>            lineParts = line.split(',')<n>            studentNames = lineParts[0]<n>            answers = lineParts[1:]<n>            for answer in answers:<n>                answers.append(answer.strip())<n>            students.append({ studentsNames: answers })<n>    with open('checkList.txt', 'r+') as f:<n>	answersToCheck = f.readlines().split('\n')<n>    for student in students:<n>       answer = student[studentNames]<n>       answersToCheck.remove(answer)<n>       for name in answersToCheck:<n>           if name in student[studentNames]:<n>               if name

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:Which effect of stress could cause death if not treated immediately? Choices:  A: age grieving person B: heart attacks C: depression D: hair loss E: headache<n><n>### Response:		<n>The stress response is a method of coping that is commonly known as the fight-or-flight response. It is a series of physiological reactions that occur in the body when in response to a stressful or dangerous situation. It is the result of our body’s alarm system which is comprised of the hypothalamus which is a part of the brain, and the pituitary gland. As stressful and dangerous situations arise in our daily lives, this alarm system is triggered and we feel a rush of stress hormones and chemicals to help you react to the stress and the danger. <n><n>### Demostration:<n>The fight-or-flig response begins in our brain, when stressful or dangerous situations that arise in our daily lives trigger our alarm system. As stressful and dangeros situations arise in our life, the alarm system is triggered and you feel a rush of chemicals, neurotransmitters and hormones to help you react to strd. The alarm system triggers a response from the hypothalamus, which produces a hormone called adrenaline. The aldrenaline circulates into the bloodstream where it is sent with other hormones, most commonly cortisol, to the major organs. Our organs will then begin to work to prepare us to react to a danger. <n><n>The stress response can cause death if not treated properly because our aldrenaline, cortisol and various hormones, make you ready for action or reaction. This may include things such as the heart working to pump more blood and the brain functioning differently. The more these hormones are in our system, the more likely we will have a stress response (fight, or flight) in certain situations and our bodies may not be able to get all them back to the normal rate and rhythm. This can lead to serious health conditions or chronic stress.  <n>

He would get up in the morning, and then put them in what state again? Choices:  A: upside down B: in motion C: active D: wakefulness E: resthold<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input/Input:<n>The teacher wants to make sure that her class prepared for the next lesson correctly, so she asks a few students to write down the answers to questions about the previous lesson.  Some of the answers they give her include, "A", "The answer was B", "I answered the questions completely", "We prepared everything perfectly", and "C".<n><n>#### Comment:<n>This is incorrect. There is no student who would put an answer of "B" in any type of response, even if it were a response with a question mark at the end, as "the answer was B" means that they wouldn't say anything about it.<n><n>```bash<n>1<n>2 1=1000<n>2=true<n>3=10<n>4=999<n>10=the correct answer is in the range between 1 and 1000<n>3=the correct answer is between<n>```<n><n>````Bash<n><n>### Demostration:<n>The teacher's question is, "What are you studying now?" She is referring to what. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:Where are all participants likely to need sports equipment? Choices:  A: dicks sporting goods B: sporting event C: mall D: sears E: sporting goods store<n><n>### Response:		<n>The sporting goods store.<n><n>### Solution:<n>* The user input is<n><n>```<n>The teacher didn't just [want, you, to, work, prepare, dinner]<n>```<n><n>which is the sentence that the instructor wants completed.<n><n>We don't need the verb in the sentences because we know them by the verb tense or subject<n><n>We first need to match the user input to the instructions in the `for` control statement.<n>Since in this example the sentence contains the word `work` there is a need for us to determine which of the words within the `for` instruction are related to work. To do this, first determine if the words in the instruction match the words in the user input:<n><n>```<n>for [work, you, to, in, store, just, prepare, did, sports, dicks, sports,]<n>```<n><n>When words match it is known as a subset to the user in the example and the instruction, which in this case, is the user input. In this example the word `work` is part of both the user output and the for input which is a subset of the user input to the instruction and instruction of the for control statement.<n><n>In programming, we have this idea of a logical AND and OR that represents the user input to the action of the response.<n><n>### Explanation<n><n>So now that we know, both the user output and user input are subsets of the for statement, is there any possibility of a subset OR of either the user output or the user input statement?<n>Can be possible that the user input and the for statement are unrelated based on what we know or can all the words within the user input be related to the for statement?<n>All the words can be related to the for statements based on the logical AND that occurs. We are left with just `prepare` `dinner` `dick` `sporting` `sport` and `store` as possible choices based on the user input and our logical AND. After choosing and removing any words that can't be part of the user choice to the `for` instruction, the sentence will read like `prepare dinner in the sporting goods store`. In order to do this the user input must have the `all` keyword in the user choice.<n><n><n># # # # #<n><n>## The instructor has provided the instructions in the following multiple choice question

Physically appealing 3: Easy on the eyes 4: Physically violent 5: Agreeable and humble 6: Strong and masculine 7: Physically handsome 8: Smart and educated 9: Fancy and flossy<n><n>### Response<n>Women tend to evaluate men more favorably when male attractiveness is associated with a low degree of testosterone. Men might use testosterone through behavioral or physical means to attract women. This is because men view women who prefer men higher in testosterone to be more physically attractive, and these high testosterone-preferring women are more likely to initiate romantic interest in the male and more likely to have a desire for multiple sexual partners[24]. These behaviors all involve displaying physical prowess or using physically aggressive means of attracting females, including competitive behaviors, sexual advances, and direct verbal threats. These behaviors demonstrate that men seek to attract females by displaying a lot of testosterone.<n><n>### 7 questions<n><n>### Question:A team of 160 people were participating in aerobic exercise at high intensity. Choices:  A: city B: toronto C: radio station D: roger that E: medieval castle<n><n>### Response:		<n>The answer is C: radio station.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The teacher doesn't want the students to just write their answers for the test but also for them to show their work. This would mean if the student would just write the answer (without saying the work) then the student did not follow the instruction, but if the student writes the answer (with say the work) then the students followed the instructions.<n><n>### Link:<n><n>1. [Video - Multiple Choice Questions](http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LKXP8vP_wZc)<n><n>### Commentary:<n>The answer for the first question is C: include examples. According to the video this question is incorrect because the answer is more than just including examples. The teacher wants more than that. Therefore, the students didn't follow the instructions for the first and the second task.<n>

" );<n>		<n><n>		}<n><n>		else if (choice==2)<n>		{<n><n>			//print statements<n>				<n>System.out.println(" you can store it anywhere you like");<n>	}<n><n>	}<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Demostration<n>Input: The teacher asked for you to write down your ideas about using a pen to create a picture and how much time you should take doing so.<n><n>### Response<n>```java<n>Scannerr keyboard =  new Scanner(System.in) ;<n><n>public class Program<n>{<n><n>	public void main(String[]args)<n>	{<n><n>	int choice=keyboad.nextInt(); //Asks user to input their choice<n><n>	if(choice==1) //Logical if statement that check to see if the user input is equal to 1 <n>	{<n><n><n>		System.outprintln(“Using a pen to create a piture takes alot of time and i think your picture should take more than two hours”);<n><n><n><n><n><n>	}<n><n>else if (choice==3)<n><n>	{<n><n>System.out.println();<n>		<n>	}<n>else <n>	{<n>	System.out.print(choice+ " is an invalid answer ");<n>	}<n><n><n><n><n>```    <n><n>

The intent here is to provide an opportunity to review and extend coding skills while being productive contributors to the site's collection of free exercises.<n><n>## Acknowledgments:<n>This work has been completed as part of the [Advent of Code 2019 Community Project](https://xabber.github.io/AoCCommunity/) to benefit students of all ages.<n>

Choices:  A: play chess B: sun themselves C: wrong house D: set table E: gettable<n><n>### Response:		<n>The teacher was expecting students to know that children can be confused when walking home and may not know who lives in a house that they are trying to reach. To help them they could ask someone who lives in the area if they can go to the house. This provides them with an answer to the problem the teacher wanted to see in the students solution.<n><n>### Input"The student is required to show all their working steps and steps are explained so students" Choices:  A. may be able to replicate their working. B. understand why they get the result they want C. understand where they are wrong and learn to correct their mistakes. D. know how to explain how they came to the correct answer. E. learn to give examples to support their point. <n><n>### Response<n>The teacher wants the students to be able to explain how they came up with their answers and it is expected that they will include explanations and examples.<n><n>### Answer all the questions that follow<n>Write only 2 letters<n><n>1. How can a teacher help students to work out who should visit a friend’s place?<n>Ans: The teacher can tell the students to look closely at the instructions to know what they should do.<n><n>2. How might the teacher help students to find out who needs sunscreen? <n>Ans: The students should be able to answer this themselves provided they have read the questions properly. They can ask each other if any of them got confused and asked if they are supposed to put sunscreen on themselves.<n><n>3. How could the students know where to go if they are lost? Ans: The teacher could help the students if they get confused by giving them a hint as to where they may be.<n><n>4. Why should the instructions be clear? Ans: If the instructions are not clear the students could be confused when they go to do the task themselves.<n><n>5. How did the teacher ask?<n>Ans:The words used in the sentences help to show how the teacher wants students to respond to the request.<n><n>6. How might the teacher use the information they collected to help students?<n>Ans: By giving more information as required they can help the students to be more focused.

I can understand why you would want to learn on your own especially with English. Your level seems to be basic or beginning where you are currently at, and you can't get too deep into vocabulary for that level. I believe in a way that's kind of the idea behind your interest in learning on her own.<n><n>With that being said I believe there are a couple of resources that could help you on your way to learning on your own. If you google resources about learning English, you should find a huge list. From there you want to go on to decide which you think is the most useful and find resources to get books or videos to help you. You also want to make sure you find resources that are easy to understand. This means that you do not plan on reading a textbook and then jumping to the answers immediately. I recommend starting off with something easier than a textbook. A simple website or app or something that has a lot of explanations before you give practice would probably help you the most in my opinion.<n><n>Hope that encourages you Emily and I hope to see you back at school soon.<n>Regards,<n>Your Friend,<n>Alice<n><n>### Instructiion: Answer the following multiple choice question for your friend, who is going to learn English on her/his own.<n><n>### Options:<n>Choice: A:  The text is written for a reader who speaks some English, can read and write simple sentences at a basic level and is eager to learn vocabulary and phrases. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:A shark swam in the background aquarium as the card players sat emotionless, what were they playing? Choices:  A: sea world B: court room C: shallow waters D: poker game E: card shark<n><n>### Response:		<n>This is what the question was supposed to ask:<n><n>### A shark swam in background of the aquarium that had a card game showing a card player in a poker game what were the card players playing<n><n><n>---<n>### Instruction<n>Write a conditional script that will answer a question based on an input value?<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>Input: What is 1+2<n>Question: What is 2<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a script that will take an input value?<n>If the input is A then the out put is 4+5<n>If the input is B then the out put is A+B<n><n>### Conditionals<n><n>### Input<n>Input: A<n><n>### Conditional<n>answer equals to 9<n><n>### Conditions<n>If the input is not A, then the output is 1+2. If the input is A, then the answer equals to 6.<n><n>### Condtional Output<n>If the input is `not A` then output is 1+ 2<n>If the input is a then output is 6<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>### Python <n><n>### Example:<n>Input: input and value<n>question: if question is not input then return value else return not question<n>output: question<n><n>### Output:<n>### Input:4<n>Question: what is 2?<n><n>### Output answer based off input<n>### Conditions:<n>If the input is 4 the out put is 6<n>If the input is anything else, the output is nothing.<n><n>### Output if input is 4:<n>6<n><n>### Output If input is not 4:<n><n>### Input and value:<n>question equal to input variable and output<n>question variable equal to input variable and conditional output<n><n><n><n>---<n><n># Instruction: Write a script that will take a conditional answer and create a list that outputs the answer in order of how it was answered.<n><n>---<n><n>### Instructiom: Write a script that uses if statements to show if answer is correct:<n>#### Demostration:  Incorrect output<n>#### Input:<n>If the number entered between A and G is correct then the script outputs "correct" If the number is not correct then the script outputs False<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>### Input:Where could you find some airplanes that are not being used? Choices:  A: war B: aircraft carrier C: sky D: graveyard E: crash<n><n>### Response:		There are various places where could find airplanes that are  not being used, and it would depend on your perspective and location.<n><n>### Conclusion: <n>If you were teaching an English class, you could assign multiple choice questions, however, it may not be as effective as asking students to write out an explanation. This is because, in a multiple choice question, you only provide one correct answer, students may see the correct answer but not be able to explain how they got there, also, the student is working on memorizing the correct answer, which will only work on a test if the students already know how to solve the question and they remember the correct answer, <n><n>### Example<n><n>Question: 	You need to find out how to add fractions. How can you use a table? <n><n>Answer:	In order to find fractions, you can use tables, a table provides a way to visually analyze a problem easily. <n><n><n>### Conclusions<n><n>Students should be taught how to use a table to make problems easier, how to complete the task of finding the sum of two fractions.<n><n>### Example 2<n><n>Input: Explain how you can find how to add fractions using tables?<n>Answer: <n><n>### Input<n><n>You need to find how many hours did a classroom work after school over four days last week. How can you use tables to find the answer? <n><n>### Answer<n><n>By using tables I can find out how many hours  the students need to complete a project. <n><n>### Conclude<n><n>Students can use tables to organize data and to visually analyze it.<n>

Add code to return the sum of all inputs.<n>// Ex: 4 2 7 7 5 5 1 0 7 4 6 1<n><n> 4 2 1 5 7 10 6 91 4<n><n>public int sum(int[] nums) {<n>// Your code goes here<n>    int sum = 0;<n>    for (int i = 0; i < nums.length; i++) {<n>        sum += nums[i];<n>    }<n><n>    return sum;<n><n>}<n><n>```<n><n>### Output:`A: Create a new file to hold all of the program<n>B: Split the program into ten sections<n>C: Write ten different files for the program<n>D: Make one program <n>E: Keep the program size under ten<n>F: Delete unnecessary parts of the program<n>G: Insert empty lines after each method as a program decoration<n>H: Change the existing code to make the code shorter<n>I: Add more statements to make it larger<n>J: Add
